context.title: Graphical Data Mapping Editor
context.description:
Create maps between input and output objects in this editor. XQuery generated from the maps is used to transform data at runtime. To create a map:
1. Add input and output objects by clicking the icons in the menu bar. 2. Select an element in the input object on the left side of the canvas, and drag the mouse to the output element on the right side of the canvas. 3. A transform is created for the mapping. The transform runs logic on the data before it is moved to the output element. To change the transform type, right-click the transform and select Change Transform.
Tips:
- To add multiple elements to a transform, connect the additional input element to the transform. - An Assign transform can be created by right-clicking an output element and then selecting Create Transform from the context menu.

context.title: Source Object
context.description: Select the source message tree.

context.title: Target Object
context.description: Select the target message tree.

context.title: Mapping Input
context.description: Select the mapping input.

topic.label: Mapping from input to output elements

context.title: Mapping Output
context.description: Select the mapping output.

topic.label: Mapping from input to output elements

context.title: Mapping Transform
context.description: Select a mapping transform.

topic.label: Transform types in the Graphical Data Mapping editor

context.title: Mapping Group
context.description: Select a mapping group.

context.title: Append Transform
context.description:
Used for iteration, removal, insertion and concatenation. This transform can have multiple inputs (either simple or complex type) and contains nested maps (similar to a Local map). The target must be an array and can be of simple or complex type.
The order of inputs into the transform is recognized, and is set in the Order page of the Properties view.
The Cardinality page in the Properties view contains interval entries for each array input.
When the transform is run, iteration is performed over each input sequentially. For example, it runs first over all elements in the first input array, then over all elements in the second input array, and so on. Inputs of single elements are allowed; they add an extra count to the iteration process. Output array size is equal to the sum of all input elements, minus the elements that are filtered out from the cardinality property page.

context.title: Assign Transform
context.description: Assign a value to the output element. The assign transform does not have an input element.

topic.label: Setting the value of output elements

context.title: Cache Failure Transform
context.description: Use the Cache Failure transform to handle any exception from a global cache operation.

context.title: Cache Get Transform
context.description: Use the Cache Get transform to retrieve a key-value pair from the global cache.

context.title: Cache Put Transform
context.description: Use the Cache Put transform to insert or update a key-value pair in the global cache.

context.title: Cache Remove Transform
context.description: Use the Cache Remove transform to remove a key-value pair from the global cache.

context.title: Cache Return Transform
context.description: Use the Cache Return transform to map from the result of a global cache operation.

context.title: Concat Transform
context.description: Use the Concat transform to concatenate data from two or more simple elements into a string output element.

context.title: If, Else If, or Else Transform
context.description:
Use a group of conditional transforms (If, Else If and Else) to control the flow of the mapping. The condition is applied to the input element of the conditional transform. If the condition is satisfied, the transform that is nested within the conditional transform is run.
1. For each conditional transform in the group, enter a condition in the Conditions tab in the Properties view. The condition must be in the form of an XPath expression. 2. To change the order in which the conditions are evaluated, select the conditional group and click the Order tab and use the up and down arrows. 3. Double-click the conditional transform (for example, If) to create the mapping that will be run for the condition.

topic.label: If, Else if, and Else transform

context.title: Convert Transform
context.description: Implement a schema type cast on the input to match the output. If the type cast cannot be performed on the input instance value, an exception will be thrown.

context.title: Create Transform
context.description: Use the Create transform to initialize an output element, set an output element to nil, or set an output element to fixed value defined by the schema.

context.title: Custom Transform
context.description: Use the Custom ESQL transform to call your own ESQL code from a graphical data map.

context.title: Custom Java Transform
context.description: Enter your own Java code to be used in the transform.

context.title: Custom XPath Transform
context.description: Enter your own XPath code to be used in the transform.

context.title: For Each Transform
context.description:
Apply this transform when there is only one array input (either a simple type or a complex type). The output must be an array of simple or complex types. Double-click the transform or right-click and select Edit to open the contained nested map. Map the elements in the nested map and apply the appropriate transform.
Iteration and removal are achieved by using the Cardinality property page to specify the indices that the transform will process. The first index element is 1. The output array size is equal to the input array size, minus the elements that are filtered out from the Cardinality property page.
Note: The For Each transform contains a nested map. The elements in the nested map must be mapped, otherwise no action will be performed when the transform runs.

context.title: Group Transform
context.description: Select the Group transform.

context.title: Join Transform
context.description:
Join multiple input arrays into a single output based on a common value, similar to the way in which tables are joined in database operations. At least one of the input elements must be an array. Input arrays need not be the same size during execution. The output element can be an array or single element but must be a complex type.
Join expression
When there are two or more input arrays, the criteria on which to join these arrays can be specified in the join expression, which is located in the General properties page. The join expression is a Boolean expression analogous to the Where clause in a database operation. If no join expression is specified, the size of the target array will be the Cartesian product of the sizes of the input arrays.
Cardinality
The Cardinality properties page enables you to filter any of the input arrays before they are joined.
Order
The Order properties page allows you to indicate the order in which the input arrays are processed, which in turn determines the order of the target array.
The Join transform contains nested maps that you need to complete. Click on the transform or right-click and select Edit to open the contained nested map. Map the elements in the nested map and apply the appropriate transforms.

context.title: Local Map Transform
context.description:
A Local Map is a transform with only one single element as input (either primitive or complex type) that can contain nested maps. The output can be a single element or an array element but must be a complex type.
Double-click the transform or right-click and Edit to open the contained nested map. Map the elements in the nested map and apply the appropriate transform.

context.title: Move Transform
context.description: Copy the data from the input element to the output element.

context.title: Normalize Transform
context.description: Use the Normalize transform to remove white space from the input string (spaces, tabs, and returns) and move the resulting normalized string to the output element.

context.title: Remove Transform
context.description: Use the Remove transform to delete an element from the Environment tree or to remove an element within an Override structure.

context.title: RDB Delete Transform
context.description: Use the Delete transform to delete one or more rows of data that match a configured "Where" clause from a database table. The name and structure of the database that you want to access are determined by the database definition file (.dbm file) that you selected from the Data Design project used to create the map.

context.title: RDB Failure Transform
context.description: Use the Failure transform to handle exceptions that are raised when accessing a database specified in another graphical data map transform. If you do not configure the Failure transform, exceptions that are raised by the database transform are ignored.

context.title: RDB Insert Transform
context.description: Use the Insert transform to insert a row of data into a database table. The name and structure of the database that you want to access are determined by the database definition file (.dbm file) that you selected from the Data Design project used to create the map.

context.title: RDB Return Transform
context.description: Use the Return transform to specify a nested mapping that is called if a database Insert, Update, or Delete transform was completed successfully. The Return transform provides an input that specifies the number of rows modified by the associated database transform.

context.title: RDB Routine Call Transform
context.description: Use the Database Routine transform to invoke a database stored procedure or a user defined function. The name and parameters of the routine that you want to execute are determined by the database definition file (.dbm file) that you selected from the Data Design project used to create the map. The data definition file does not specify the columns of the result sets from the executing the routine. To map from any result set column, you have to use the toolkit to define result sets and their columns for the routine.

context.title: RDB Routine Return Transform
context.description: Use the Return transform of a Database Routine for mappings from the output parameters, a return value, and results sets after executing a routine. The parameters and the presence of a return value of the procedure that you want to execute are determined by the database definition file. The name and structure of the routine that you want to access are determined by the database definition file. You need to define the result sets from the routine using the Toolkit. You need to include all columns you want to map from in one of the result sets.

context.title: RDB Select Transform
context.description: Use the Select transform to use rows from a database table as input data in a graphical data map. The name and structure of the database that you want to access are determined by the database definition file (.dbm file) that you selected from the Data Design project used to create the map.

context.title: RDB Update Transform
context.description: Use the Update transform to modify one or more rows of data that match a configured "Where" clause from a database table. Optionally, if no rows of data match your configured "Where" clause, the Update transform can insert a row of data. The name and structure of the database that you want to access are determined by the database definition file (.dbm file) that you selected from the Data Design project used to create the map.

context.title: Submap Transform
context.description: Invoke a graphical data map from another map file, which can be stored in an application, library, or project. Choosing this transform type is most effective for reuse purposes.

context.title: Substring Transform
context.description: Use the Substring transform to set the value of an output element to a substring of the original input value. You use this transform to extract a subset of characters that are separated by a delimiter based on a position that you indicate with an index.

context.title: Task Transform
context.description: Use the Task transform to indicate a manual task or point of concern that might need to be resolved before a message map can be used in your solution.

context.title: General - Assign
context.description: Enter a value that will be copied to the output element.

context.title: Cardinality Property Page
context.description:
Set the indices of the input and output array elements that the transform will operate over. The input index can be set to include multiple indices but the output entry allows only a single index.
Examples:
- • All indices -> * (or no entry) - • Only index 5 -> 5 - • Indices 1 though 3 -> 1:3 • Indices 1, 3, and 5 -> 1,3,5 - • Indices 2 and up -> 2:* - • Indices 1, 3, 5 and up -> 1,3,5:* - • Indices 2 through 8, but not 5 -> 2:4,6:8 - • All indices but 5 -> 1:4,6:*

topic.label: Selecting the indices of input and output array elements

context.title: Group Transform General Property Page
context.description: Specify the Group transform property.

context.title: Input or Output Object General Property Page - Name
context.description: Specify the Name property.

context.title: Input or Output Object General Property Page - Namespace
context.description: Displays the Namespace of the map.

context.title: Order
context.description:
Specify the order in which input elements will be processed by the transform. On Submap transforms, you can use this page to align the inputs of the transform to the input parameters of the referenced Submap.
There can be only one output element, so the output element order is not applicable to a graphical data map.

context.title: Order Property Page - Mapping Declaration
context.description: Specify the Mapping Declaration.

context.title: Order - Conditional Mapping Group
context.description: Set the order of execution for the If and Else if transforms by using the up and down arrows. The first transform must be an If and the last transform must be an else. If you move an Else if transform to the top of the list, it becomes anIf transform.

topic.label: IF, Else if and Else transforms

context.title: Sort Property Page
context.description: Enable Sorting of reapting elements and specify the Sort properties.

context.title: Submap Transform General Property Page
context.description: Select the graphical data map that will be used in the transform.

context.title: Input or Output Object General Property Page - Type
context.description: Specify the Type property.

context.title: Documentation Property Page
context.description: Enter text to Document the transform.

context.title: Filter Inputs Property Page
context.description: Set "Allow Empty" to have the transform still entered once if the input array element is empty or no inputs match a provided condition.

context.title: Cache Put General Property Page - Cache Put Mode
context.description: Choose what to do when Cache Put is invoked and the key for the cache entry is present or absent.

context.title: Find Dialog
context.description: See the IBM Integration information center.

context.title: Automap Wizard
context.description: Use the Auto map wizard to map elements by examining the names of input and output elements to create mappings.

topic.label: Automatically mapping input to output elements

context.title: XPath Expression Builder
context.description: See the IBM Integration information center.

context.title: Simple XPath Expression Builder
context.description: Use the XPath Expression Builder to aid creating XPath expressions with context assist, by pressing Ctrl+space.

context.title: Condition
context.description: Specify an XPath expression as a condition, use context assist by pressing Ctrl+space. The transform will execute only if the condition is fulfilled.

context.title: Filter Inputs Property Page
context.description: Specify an XPath expression as a condition, use context assist by pressing Ctrl+space. Each element of the repeatable input will be tested against the condition. The transform will execute for those elements that satisfy the condition. The Allow Empty option means the transform is entered once if the input array element is empty or no inputs match the condition.

context.title: Custom Java Transform General Property Page
context.description: Write your own Java code, or call reference code to be used in the transform.

context.title: Custom XPath Transform General Property Page
context.description: Write your own transform as an XPath expression. Click the icon next to the editable field to select user defined functions. When you add such a function, it becomes available for use in the XPath expression. If you type Ctrl-Space, you will see the added function in the list of available functions.

context.title: Join Transform General Property Page
context.description:
Joins elements from two or more input arrays. The target element can be an array or single element but must be a complex type. Input arrays need not be the same size during execution.
Indicate which input array to iterate over, and the indices of the arrays that the transform will operate over. When there are no more elements left in this array, the transform will end.
While it is running, the iteration is performed over each array input in unison. For example, it first operates on index 1 over all inputs and output, then operates on index 2 over all inputs and output, and so on. Iterations over the smaller array inputs on an index that is out of its bounds will ignore any associated mappings. Inputs of single elements are allowed and are treated as constants over each iteration. Output array size is equal to the size of the input array that is chosen for iteration.

context.title: Cast Property Page
context.description: Displays the input and output elements that have a schema Cast function applied to redefine them.

context.title: Convert transform General Property Page
context.description: Set the Convert transform properties.

context.title: XPath/EXSLT Function Call General Property Page
context.description: Set the properties for the XPath/EXSLT function call.

context.title: Format Date Function Call General Property Page
context.description: See the IBM Integration information center.

context.title: Java Imports Property Page
context.description: View the assigned prefix for Java imports used in Custom Java transforms and add imports for using Java in condition expressions.

context.title: Namespaces Property Page
context.description: Set the Namespace properties.

context.title: Scope Property Page
context.description: The Scope properties display the schema files that are referenced. Click Add to include additional schema files to enable cuasting input or output elements.

context.title: Transform Variables Property Page
context.description: Set the transform variables properties.

context.title: Add Input or Output Dialog
context.description: Add input or output to the graphical data map.

context.title: Submap Selection Dialog
context.description: Select a submap.
Import a database model from a connected database.
Make a database model available in the workspace.
Configure database select.

context.title: Configuration Update Table Dialog
context.description: Update a database table.
Properties for database input and output.

description.b: Database model of a result set column.

context.description: Use these settings to enable input source checks and specify what to set in the Database target column. Some actions will only be available depending on the configuration of the database column.

topic.label: Behavior when modifying database column values from optional source elements
Modifying data in a database by using mapping

description.b: Select your Custom ESQL method and set the parameters.
Displays the ESQL files that are imported for use in Custom ESQL transfroms.
